repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - Second Economic Reform Support
            Operation Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Second Economic
            Reform Support Operation Credit Project for Ghana were as
            follows: the outcome was unsatisfactory, the sustainability
            was substantial, the institutional development impact was
            negligible, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            unsatisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that the recent
            Bank support to adjustment in Ghana has been provided under
            a series of Economic Reform Support Operations: Economic
            Reform Support Operation - ERSO I, II, and III. Progress in
            the implementation of the ERSOs has been uneven and
            experience points to the following main lessons: (i)
            Pressing financial needs was a primary reason to proceed
            fast with ERSO II and III. Both Credits were prepared in
            about 3 months. When there is a need to act fast, there is a
            basis to be cautious about the depth of the
            Government's commitment; (ii) Despite satisfactory
            identification of risks, mitigation measures related to the
            political environment and capacity may not be able to
            overcome the problem of an ambitious Credit design. The
            above shortcomings can be tackled in an environment such as
            the one provided by programmatic lending under the PRSCs in
            which resource transfer decisions are linked to achievements
            in the implementation of the country's medium-term
            poverty reduction strategies.

Ghana - Second Economic Reform Support

5081622.trustfund:
TF029418-PHRD-NUTRITION & CHILD DEV. PROJ.,TF023354-REPUBLIC OF GHANA -- SECOND

5081622.majtheme: Trade and integration,Financial and private sector development,Economic management,Public sector governance

repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - Second Economic Reform Support
            Operation Credit Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Economic Reform Support
            Operation Credit Project for Ghana seeks to consolidate
            recent gains in restoring macroeconomic stability and will
            support the implementation of a deeper phase of the reform
            program in the cocoa, energy, and banking sectors. Fiscal
            policies supported under the credit improve fiscal
            sustainability while raising the efficiency of resource
            mobilization and use. In particular, the termination of
            specific road contracts removes an important source of
            fiscal imbalance and resource misallocation. Also,
            eliminating the "special tax" on imports begins a
            process to further rationalize the import tariff regime so
            as to provide adequate incentives to local industry within a
            regional context. Very importantly, the Credit will
            implement a revised strategy for the cocoa sector developed
            with strong stakeholder ownership. As part of this strategy,
            the increase in the farmers' share of the fob price
            will be further accelerated while external marketing will be
            gradually opened to private competition. The Credit
            implements key elements of the remaining reform agenda by
            establishing market regulations, divesting the distribution
            units of Ghana's electric company, enhancing financial
            system soundness by targeting the closure of distressed
            banks, and continuing the divestiture of the remaining
            government banks. The Credit helps cover Ghana's
            external financing requirements while it assists in reducing
            the government's domestic financing requirements.
